_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Yenter Gas Plant Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) was prepared for Sterling Energy Company's (SEC) Yenter Gas Plant Facility located west of Sterling, Colorado.  The primary activity at the Yenter Gas Plant Facility (Facility) is the handling and compression of natural gas.  In addition, as part of the facility operation, natural gas liquids (NGL) are separated from the natural gas stream, stored on site, and sold to offsite facilities.  The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to strive for the prevention of NGL accidental releases from the Facility and to reduce the severity of any releases which may occur.

The flammable regulated chemical mixture at the Yenter Facility is Natural Gas Liquids (NGL) which is an aliphatic and aromatic hydrocarbon mixture.  The flammable regulated chemicals contained in the mixture included N-pentane, isopentane, N-butane, isobutene, propane, and ethane.  These regulated chemicals have a RMP regulated threshold quantity limit (TQL) of 10,000 pounds.  The chemical abstract service (CAS) number for NGL is not applicable.  However the CAS number for the individual constituents are as follows:  Pentane 109-66-0, Isopentane 78-78-4, Butane 106-97-8, Isobutane 75-28-5, Propane 74-98-6, Ethane 74-84-0 and Methane 74-82-8.

The Yenter Facility stores up to 183,000 gallons of NGL in 26 above ground storage tanks.  The tanks contain a maximum of 632,193 pounds of regulated flammable chemicals.  

The RMP*COMPTM  program developed by the CAMEO team at the Hazardous Materials Response and Assessment Division of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Chemical Emergency Prevention and Preparedness Office of the Environmental Protection Agency was applied for the worst case release scenario (WCRS).  The worst case scenario was assumed to be the release of the total quantity of the 60,0000 gallon bulk storage tank forming a vapor cloud within the lower and upper flammability limit

s which detonates.  For flammable substances, the endpoint is overpressure of 1 pound per square inch (psi) for vapor cloud explosions.  The release parameters are:  wind speed 1/5 meters per second (m/s), and atmospheric stability F.

Using the flammable endpoint of 1-psi overpressure and the data contained in the RMP*COMPTM program, the WCRS distance was calculated at 0.5 miles from the Facility.  Based on a site visit of the adjacent properties within a 0.5 mile radius of the facility, the population within the WCRS area is zero (0).  Public receptors, as defined in 40 CFR 68.3, within 0.5 miles of the Facility, were not observed.  Environmental receptors, as defined by 40 CFR 68.3, within 0.5 miles of the Facility, were not observed based on review of United States Geologic Survey (USGS) topographic maps.  The Facility has not had a NGL release during the past five years.

The Facility has an Emergency Response Program which includes an Emergency Response Plan.  The Emergency Response Plan describes procedures to minimize hazards to human health and the environment.  The Emergency Response Plan includes aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  The Emergency Response Plan also includes procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and its inspection, testing and maintenance.  In the event of a NGL accident, first aid procedures for exposure, as well as procedures to inform authorities and the public are described in the Emergency Response Plan.  A general emergency practice drill is performed at least annually and includes an invitation to the appropriate local authorities.  A site map, MSDSs, and a list of chemicals are kept at the Facility and on the site in an emergency box located in an accessable location should there be a release or other emergency.  This Emergency Respo

nse Plan is kept both at the Facility and in the the emergency box and should be referenced in the event of a release.  The Emergency Response Plan is updated and reviewed as appropriate to reflect changes at the facility and the covered process.  Employees are informed of changes and trained in procedures and to used applicable equipment.
